subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Letter connections and syllable boundaries (or, the spelling of "kangaroo")
msgSnippet: Sorry John - as a South Eastern England speaker, Thaw-Et-Fee-Tea and Fee-Et-Fee-Tee are two different sounds. I find I am getting very confused with the names
messageBody:
Sorry John - as a South Eastern England speaker, Thaw-Et-Fee-Tea and Fee-Et-Fee-Tee are two different sounds.

I find I am getting very confused with the names for the letters which you are all using.  I know the QM names, 
and I have all John Zuk's names (which I like) but I dont understand these new names you all seem to be using.  
Where to they come from?

Moira

On 26/11/2007, John Cowan <cowan@...> wrote:

Anthony Grahn scripsit:

> So this new letter, while it may aid reading (so far as I know the
> problem being addressed is only a readability problem), could greatly
> impede writing. Trying to decide whether to use THAW vs THEY is a fine
> example of a grapheme-phoneme separation that greatly slows writing.

 It can't be helped. It's better that someone in Southeast England
hesitates whether to write Thaw-Et-Fee-Tea or Fee-Et-Fee-Tee
(which sound the same to her) and maybe has to look it up,
than that Americans can't tell whether Low-Awe-Day is "lord"
or "laud" (which likewise sound the same to her).

--
The man that wanders far cowan@...
from the walking tree http://www.ccil.org/~cowan
--first line of a non-existent poem by: John Cowan




--
Moira O'Brien
